SENT.plain: PURPOSE: To assess the relationship between the presence of pets in homes of epilepsy patients and the occurrence of sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP)

METHODS: Parents or relatives of SUDEP patients collected over a ten-year period (2000-2009) in a large epilepsy unit were asked if the patient lived together with any domestic pet at the time of death or not
Patients who did not experience SUDEP served as controls
RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONS: Eleven out of the 1092 included patients (1%) experienced SUDEP, all with refractory symptomatic epilepsy, but none of them had pets in their homes at the time of death
In contrast, the frequency of pet-ownership in the control group (n=1081) was 61%

According to previous studies there are some indications that human health is directly related to companionship with animals in a way that domestic animals prevent illness and facilitate recovery of patients
Companion animals can buffer reactivity against acute stress, diminish stress perception and improve physical health
These factors may reduce cardiac arrhythmias and seizure frequency, factors related to SUDEP
Companion animals may have a positive effect on well-being, thus improving epilepsy outcome
